results.name: Number of solutions of the equation (n+k)' = n' + k', with 1 <= k <= 2n, where n' denotes the arithmetic derivative of n.
comment: Observe that when n and c*n have the same parity, a(c*n) >= a(n) for all integers c. For even n, there are always at least two solutions, k=n/2 and k=2n. For odd n, k=2n is always a solution.
a(A258138(n)) = n and a(m) != n for m < A258138(n). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, May 21 2015
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
mathematica: dn[0]=0; dn[1]=0; dn[n_]:=Module[{f=Transpose[FactorInteger[n]]}, If[PrimeQ[n], 1, Plus@@(n*f[[2]]/f[[1]])]]; Table[lst={}; k=0; While[k<2n, k++; While[k<=2n && dn[n]+dn[k] != dn[n+k], k++ ]; If[dn[n]+dn[k]==dn[n+k], AppendTo[lst, k]]]; Length[lst], {n, 100}]
program: f x ad = y : f (x + 1) (h (3 * x + 1) ad)  where
let x' = ad ! x, ad ! (x + k) == x' + ad ! k]
